stimulusHtml:
Show all your work. Indicate clearly the methods you use, because you will be scored on the correctness of your methods as well as on the accuracy and completeness of your results and explanations.

 

Orthodontists use Temporary Anchoring Devices (TADs) to keep teeth in place. TADs can be made of stainless steel or titanium. A certain amount of damage is expected during use of the TADs, but too much damage to the TADs could result in a failure to achieve the desired results. An experiment was performed to compare the mean amount of damage to TADs made of stainless steel to the mean amount of damage to TADs made of titanium. Researchers recruited 386 volunteer orthodontic patients requiring TADs to participate in the experiment. Each volunteer had a TAD made of stainless steel placed on one side of the mouth and a TAD made of titanium placed on the other side of the mouth. For each volunteer, a flip of a fair coin determined which side of the mouth, left (Heads) or right (Tails), received the TAD made of stainless steel. The other side of the mouth received the TAD made of titanium. After six months, an orthodontist recorded the amount of damage observed on each TAD on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 representing the least damage and 10 representing the most damage.

(a) Identify the experimental units and treatments in the context of this experiment.

  • Experimental units
     
  • Treatments

(b) Consider the design of this experiment.

(i) Identify the experimental design.

(ii) Characteristics of each volunteer, such as age, diet, and dental hygiene, influence the amount of damage to a TAD. Explain how the design of this experiment controls for the effects of these characteristics.
(c) What would it mean for this experiment to be single-blind?

(d) Suppose the experiment showed no significant difference in the mean amount of damage between the two types of TADs. Can these results be generalized to all orthodontic patients requiring TADsâ€Š? Justify your response.
